skill.name: polars
skill.description: Fast in-memory DataFrame library for datasets that fit in RAM. Use when pandas is too slow but data still fits in memory. Lazy evaluation, parallel execution, Apache Arrow backend. Best for 1-100GB datasets, ETL pipelines, faster pandas replacement. For larger-than-RAM data use dask or vaex.
skill.summary: Fast in-memory DataFrame library for datasets that fit in RAM. Use when pandas is too slow but data ...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This skill contains ONLY markdown documentation files with Python code examples. All 690 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The analyzer misidentified markdown code blocks, Python syntax, and Polars library methods as security threats. No executable code, shell commands, credential access, or network operations exist.

content.value_statement: Process large datasets in memory with Polars, the high-performance DataFrame library. Features lazy evaluation, parallel execution, and Apache Arrow backend for 10x faster operations than pandas.
actual_capabilities: Create and manipulate DataFrames with expression-based API
Filter, select, group, and aggregate data efficiently
Read and write CSV, Parquet, JSON, Excel, and cloud storage formats
Perform joins, pivots, concatenations, and reshaping operations
Use lazy evaluation for query optimization and memory efficiency
Migrate from pandas with guided syntax mapping
limitations: Data must fit in RAM (use dask or vaex for larger-than-memory datasets)
No built-in machine learning or statistical modeling functions
Limited visualization capabilities (use with matplotlib or plotly)
String operations have different syntax than pandas

use_cases.title: Build ETL pipelines
use_cases.description: Create efficient data pipelines with lazy evaluation for memory optimization and parallel execution.

use_cases.title: Transform and aggregate data
use_cases.description: Filter, group, and aggregate large datasets with expression-based syntax and window functions.

use_cases.title: Replace pandas with faster alternative
use_cases.description: Migrate existing pandas code to Polars for significant performance improvements on medium datasets.

prompt_templates.title: Load and explore data
prompt_templates.prompt: Load a CSV file with Polars and show the first rows, column types, and basic statistics.

prompt_templates.title: Filter and select
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter rows where a column meets a condition and select specific columns using Polars expressions.

prompt_templates.title: Group and aggregate
prompt_templates.prompt: Group data by one or more columns and compute aggregations like mean, sum, and count.

prompt_templates.title: Lazy optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert this DataFrame operation to use lazy evaluation and explain the performance benefits.

output_examples.input: Load a CSV file and filter rows where age is greater than 25
output: Created DataFrame with columns: name, age, city

output_examples.input: Group sales data by product category and calculate total and average sales
output: Calculated sum and mean of sales_amount

output_examples.input: Read a Parquet file using lazy evaluation and collect only needed columns

best_practices: Use scan_csv or scan_parquet with lazy evaluation for large datasets to enable query optimization
Filter and select columns early in your pipeline to reduce memory usage and improve performance
Prefer native Polars expressions over Python functions to enable parallel execution
anti_patterns: Avoid using read_csv on large files when lazy evaluation would suffice
Do not apply Python functions inside hot paths when Polars expressions can accomplish the same task
Avoid loading entire datasets into memory when streaming with collect(streaming=True) would work

faq.question: How is Polars different from pandas?
faq.answer: Polars has no index, uses strict typing, offers lazy evaluation, and parallelizes operations by default. It is faster for medium-sized datasets.

faq.question: When should I use lazy evaluation?
faq.answer: Use lazy evaluation for large datasets, complex pipelines, or when performance matters. It enables query optimization before execution.

faq.question: What data sizes work best with Polars?
faq.answer: Polars excels with datasets from 1MB to 100GB that fit in RAM. Use dask or vaex for larger-than-memory data.

faq.question: Can I migrate from pandas easily?
faq.answer: Yes, the migration is straightforward with similar concepts but different syntax. Most operations map directly to Polars equivalents.

faq.question: Does Polars support cloud storage?
faq.answer: Yes, Polars reads and writes to S3, Azure Blob Storage, and Google Cloud Storage with proper credentials configured.

faq.question: What file formats does Polars support?
faq.answer: Polars supports CSV, Parquet, JSON, Excel, IPC/Arrow, and databases via connectors. Parquet is recommended for performance.
